about: Waits until the Unix Timestamp specified (in milliseconds) before continuing the code.

Game Changer – My terrible pun of a project. This uses the timestamp to cycle between each game in “Minigames 2”, resulting in a different game played each day.

other_info: If you try to copy this block in the latest version of the app, Hopscotch will crash.

useful_for: Creating Synchronized Projects that will show the same thing on all devices at any given time

about: Moves the object in their forward direction by the specified distance (pixels)
community_links: There are no tutorials on this block yet. Why not create one? Actually, there probably is a tutorial. Linking it to my topic would be appreciated.
description:
Moves your object forward* by the number of pixels specified. Negative numbers will move you robject backwards.
*Forward means the angle your object is facing. All objects face to the right by default - 0 degrees. You can turn or flip an object to change the direction of Move Forward.

name: Move Forward

parameters.description: Distance – The number of pixels to move in the forward direction.

about: Turns the object by the number of degrees specified.

name: Turn degrees

Sets a special number for your project to remember. Give this number a unique name. Your new variable appears as an oval block that you can add to any number field, math operation or Set Text. This saved number can be changed later in your code by using the Increase block or using Set again.

about: Saves a user text input to a variable

For example, if you were making a mad libs game, you could use this block to ask players to enter a verb. You'd simply add the block, change the prompt to 'Enter a verb,' and then the variable will be set to whatever word they enter.

about: Plays a music note for the length of a given note type

The rhythm is based on the object's tempo in beats per minute. A quarter note is considered one beat. The default tempo is 120 beats per minute, meaning that one beat would last for 1/2 second. You can use the tempo trait block to find the current tempo.

about: Sets the tempo, or speed, of the music in beats per minute.

Note: The default tempo is 120 beats per minute, meaning that one beat would last for 1/2 second. You can use the tempo trait block to find the current tempo.

about: Checks if two numbers or texts are equal to each other.
description:
Used with numbers, text and variables to test if they have the same value. Returns true if text is exactly equal or if numbers are exactly equal.
Examples: 
cow = cow will return true
cow = Cow will return false (the second cow has an uppercase C so they are not the same) 
3 = 3 will return true 
3 = cow will return false
3 = 4 will return false

parameters.description: Source – A number or text you want to compare.
Target – The number or text you want to compare the source item to.

about: Checks if two numbers or texts are NOT equal to each other.
description:
This symbol means not equal. This is used with numbers, text and variables to test if they have different values. Returns true if text is not exactly equal or numbers are not equal.
Examples: 
cow ≠ Cow returns true (the second cow has an uppercase C so they are not the same) 
cow ≠ cow returns false
3 ≠ cow returns true
3 ≠ 4 returns true
3 ≠ 3 returns false

parameters.description: Source – A number or text you want to compare.
Target – The number or text you want to compare the source item to.

about: Checks whether the first number is less than the second number (when comparing numbers), or if the first text comes before the second text when sorting alphabetically (when comparing strings)
description:
This symbol means less than. This is used with numbers, text and variables to see if the first value is smaller than the second one. If they are equal it will return false.
Examples: 
ant < cow returns true (ant is earlier in the alphabet than cow)
cow < cow return false (they are equal) 
cow < Cow returns true (lowercase text comes before uppercase text) 
1 < cow returns true (numbers come before text)
1 < 3 returns true 
1 < 1 returns false
name: <

parameters.description: Source – A number or text you want to compare.
Target – The number or text you want to compare the source item to.
parameters.label: <

about: Checks whether the first number is greater than the second number (when comparing numbers), or if the first text comes after the second text when sorting alphabetically (when comparing strings)
description:
This symbol means greater than. This is used with numbers, text and variables to see if the first value is larger than the second one. If they are equal it will return false.
Examples: 
cow > ant returns true (cow is later in the alphabet than ant)
cow > cow returns false (cow is equal to cow)
Cow > cow returns true (uppercase text comes after lowercase text) 
cow > 1 returns true (numbers come before text)
11 > 3 returns true 
1 > 1 returns false
name: >

parameters.description: Source – A number or text you want to compare.
Target – The number or text you want to compare the source item to.
parameters.label: >

Examples: 
cow >= ant returns true (cow is later in the alphabet than ant)

Cow >= cow returns true (uppercase text comes after lowercase text)

11 >= 3 returns true

parameters.description: Source – A number or text you want to compare.

description:
This symbol means less than. This is used with numbers, text and variables to see if the first value is smaller than the second one. If they are equal it will return true.
Examples: 
ant <= cow returns true (ant is earlier in the alphabet than cow)
cow <= cow return true (they are equal) 
cow <= Cow returns true (lowercase text comes before uppercase text) 
1 <= cow returns true (numbers come before text)
1 <= 3 returns true 
1 <= 1 returns true

parameters.description: Source – A number or text you want to compare.
Target – The number or text you want to compare the source item to.

about: Determines whether the first string contains, or matches, the second string, which can either be a string (literal) or a regular expression.
description:
This will perform a match of slot 1 to slot 2 to see if slot 2 has a string of text or numbers that matches slot 1. (This can be used with variables.) 
For example, "crow" matches "cow" will return false, because "crows" has an "r" that slot 2 doesn't have. Similarly, "o" matches "cow" returns false, because slot 1 doesn't have a "c" or a "w" in the string. However, "cow" matches "o" returns true, because slot 1 has an "o."
When mixing text and numbers, the number gets converted to text and the 2 slots are compared as text. "cow3" matches "3" will return true, but "3" matches "cow" will return false.
Advanced users can try using regular expressions for more complicated matches.
name: matches
other_info: Note: Regular expression matching functionality is not limited to advanced mode. "Advanced users" in the help text refers to "experienced/power users pushing the boundaries of Hopscotch" – and not "someone who is using advanced mode"

parameters.description: Text – The text you want to scan for a match.
Expression – A string or regular expression (without bounding slashes) that the text should contain/match
parameters.label: matches

about: Measures how much the user has tilted their device down, where 0% is a device laying flat on a table and 100% is holding a device upside-down.
description:
This gives you the degree to which the top of the device is facing down. If you hold your device so that your screen is upside-down, this value is 100%.
You can use this to detect which way the screen is facing.
label: ▶️ Tilt Down %
name: ▶️ Tilt Down %
other_info: Percentages range from -100% to 100%

about: Measures how much the user has tilted their device left.
description:
This gives you the degree to which the left side of the screen is being tilted toward the floor. If you tilt the left side of the screen down, 'Tilt Left %' will be greater than 0. 
You can use this to detect which way the screen is facing.
label: ▶️ Tilt Left %
name: ▶️ Tilt Left %
other_info: Percentages range from -100% to 100%

about: Measures how much the user has tilted their device right.
description:
This gives you the degree to which the right side of the screen is being tilted toward the floor. If you tilt the right side of the screen down, 'Tilt Right %' will be greater than 0.
You can use this to detect which way the screen is facing.
label: ▶️ Tilt Right %
name: ▶️ Tilt Right %
other_info: Percentages range from -100% to 100%

about: Retrieves the x-coordinate (distance from left side of screen) of the last point touched on the screen.
blockHTML: ▶️ Last Touch X
description: Records the last point on the screen you touched from left to right. Use this block with the Draw a Trail block to make drawing pads.
label: ▶️ Last Touch X
name: ▶️ Last Touch X
other_info: When your screen size is different from the stage size, this will not always be a whole number.

about: Retrieves the y-coordinate (distance from bottom of screen) of the last point touched on the screen.
blockHTML: ▶️ Last Touch Y
description: Records the last point on the screen you touched from top to bottom. Use this block with the Draw a Trail block to make drawing pads.
label: ▶️ Last Touch Y
name: ▶️ Last Touch Y
other_info: When your screen size is different from the stage size, this will not always be a whole number.

about: Returns the total number of objects, including clones, that are on the screen.
description: Tracks the total number of objects (including all clones) on the screen.
label: ▶️ Total Objects
name: ▶️ Total Objects

about: Adds two numbers or concatenates (joins) two strings
description:
This adds the two numbers you enter: (5+2=7). 
You can use variables (my_variable + 2) to have the total of the block change as the variable changes. 
You can also enter text, and it will "concatenate" the text, meaning it will join the 2 pieces of text together into 1 (for example: "moo" + "cow" = "moocow").
name: Add

parameters.description: Argument – A number to add or string to concatenate.
Argument – A number to add or string to concatenate.

about: Subtracts one number from another
description: You can do the math! Works just like normal subtraction (5-3=2). You can also use variables (my_variable - 2) to have the total of the block change as the variable changes.
name: Subtract

parameters.description: Minuend – The number to start with.
Subtrahend – The number to subtract from the starting number.

about: Multiplies two numbers together, returning the product
description: You can do the math! Works just like normal subtraction (5-3=2). You can also use variables (my_variable - 2) to have the total of the block change as the variable changes.
name: Multiply

parameters.description: Factor – A number to multiply.
Factor – A number to multiply.

about: Divides one number by another
description: You can do the math! Works just like normal division (10 / 2= 5). You can also use variables (my_variable / 2) to have the total of the block change as the variable changes.
name: Divide

parameters.description: Dividend – The number to start with.
Divisor – The number to divide the dividend by.

about: Generates a random number between the minimum number and maximum number (inclusive, meaning the result can be the min or max)
description: Picks a random number between two numbers that you choose. For example, you can use Random to pick a number between 1 and 10. Add the Random block into any number or color field. Try using Random to pick random colors or line widths, move to random places, or travel random distances.
label: random
name: Random

parameters.description: Minimum – The lower possible integer to generate.
Maximum – The highest possible integer to generate.
parameters.label: to

about: Raises one number to the power of another. You can also use it to take any nth root of a number by raising it to the (1 ÷ n).
description: You can do the math! Works just like normal exponents (3^2 = 9). You can also use variables (my_variable^2 - 2) to have the total of the block change as the variable changes.
name: Power

parameters.description: Base – The number you are raising to a certain degree.
Exponent – The number of degrees to raise the base to.

about: Takes the square root of a number, i.e. √9 = 3
description: You can do the math! Works just like normal square roots (√9 = 3). You can also use variables (√my_variable - 2) to have the total of the block change as the variable changes.
name: Square Root

parameters.description: Radicand – The number you are taking a square root of.

about: The trigonometric function that is equal to the ratio of the side opposite a given angle (in a right triangle) to the hypotenuse
description: Sine is based on a right triangle. It is calculated by choosing an angle and dividing the triangle side opposite that angle by the triangle's hypotenuse. Search the community for sine and cosine to see examples of cool visuals.
label: sin
name: Sine

parameters.description: Degrees – The number of degrees to perform the sine operation on.

about: The trigonometric function that is equal to the ratio of the side adjacent to an acute angle (in a right-angled triangle) to the hypotenuse
description: Cosine is based on a right triangle. It is calculated by choosing an angle and dividing the triangle side adjacent, or next to, that angle by the triangle's hypotenuse. Search the community for sine and cosine to see examples of cool visuals.
label: cos
name: Cosine

parameters.description: Degrees – The number of degrees to perform the cosine operation on.

about: Finds the closest integer to the one provided, raising .5 to the higher number.
description:
This will give you the whole number that is closest to your number. It's called "round" because if numbers were pizza pies, a whole number would representing the whole pizza pie. A fraction or decimal would be only a piece of the pie. A whole pie is rounder than just a slice – hence the word round! 
example: 
round(2.5) will return 3
round(2.4999999) will return 2
label: round
name: Round

parameters.description: Number – The number to round to the nearest integer.

about: Finds the distance from zero to the number provided. In other words, it returns the positive value of that number
description: The distance a number is from 0. Think of a number line with 0 in the middle, negative numbers to the left, and positive numbers to the right. The absolute value of -2 is 2, because it is 2 whole numbers away from the middle.
label: absolute value
name: Absolute Value

parameters.description: Number – The number to take the absolute value of.

about: Returns the remainder of division between two numbers. For example, 5 % 2 is 1 because the remainder when dividing 5 by 2 is 2 with a remainder of 1
description: Sometimes numbers don't divide perfectly. For those occasions, use this block to find the remainder! For example, Modulo (9, 4) = 1 because 4 fits into 9 twice with 1 left over.
name: Modulo

parameters.description: Dividend – The number to start with.
Divisor – The number to divide by.

about: The trigonometric function that is equal to the ratio of the sides (other than the hypotenuse) opposite and adjacent to an angle in a right triangle.
description: Tangent is based on a right triangle. It is calculated by choosing an angle and dividing the triangle side opposite that angle by the side adjacent, or next to it. Search the community for tangent to see examples of cool visuals.
label: tan
name: Tangent

parameters.description: Degrees – The number of degrees to perform the tangent operation on.

about: A mathematical function that is the inverse of the sine function. Used to retrieve an angle given the y-coordinate in the Unit Circle.
description: You can think of inverse sine as a way to get back the original angle from a sine operation, if the angle is between -90 and 90 degrees. So if sine(30 degrees) = 0.5, then inverse sine(0.5) = 30.
label: arcsin
name: Inverse Sine

parameters.description: Input – The number to perform the inverse sine operation on.

about: A mathematical function that is the inverse of the cosine function. Used to retrieve an angle given the x-coordinate in the Unit Circle.
description: You can think of inverse cosine as a way to get back the original angle from a cosine operation, if the angle is between -90 and 90 degrees. So if cosine(60 degrees) = 0.5, then inverse cosine(0.5) = 60.
label: arccos
name: Inverse Cosine

parameters.description: Input – The number to perform the inverse cosine operation on.

about: A mathematical function that is the inverse of the tangent function. Used to retrieve an angle given the quotient of the y and x-coordinates in the Unit Circle.
description: You can think of inverse tangent as a way to get back the original angle from a tangent operation, if the angle is between -90 and 90 degrees. So if tangent(45 degrees) = 1, then inverse tangent(1) = 45.
label: arctan
name: Inverse Tangent

parameters.description: Input – The number to perform the inverse tangent operation on.

about: Returns the larger of two numbers or the string that comes last when sorting alphabetically.
description:
Will return the larger of two numbers or text. This is useful if you want to ensure a value never goes below zero when you are setting an object's scale (so it doesn't go upside down!). 
You can also enter text instead of numbers, and the text that comes later in the alphabet will be the maximum (the maximum of "cow" and "frog" is "frog"). Text also comes after numbers, so the maximum of "cow" and "3" is "cow".
label: max
name: Maximum

parameters.description: Input – A number or string to compare.
Input – A number or string to compare.

about: Returns the smaller of two numbers or the string that comes first when sorting alphabetically.
description:
Will return the lesser of two numbers or text. This is useful if you want to make sure your object does not get too large for the screen. For example, you could use the minimum function to ensure that your object's width is always less than the device's width. 
You can also enter text instead of numbers, and the text that comes earlier in the alphabet will be the minimum (the minimum of "cow" and "frog" is "cow"). Numbers also come before text, so the minimum of "cow" and "3" is "3".
label: min
name: Minimum

parameters.description: Input – A number or string to compare.
Input – A number or string to compare.

about: Returns the nearest integer that is less than or equal to the one provided; rounds a number down.
description:
This will give you the nearest whole number that is less than or equal to your number. It's called 'floor' because the floor is below you, and the floor block will return a number below your number.
example: 
floor(3.999) will return 3
floor(3) will also return 3!
label: floor
name: Floor

parameters.description: Number – The number to round down.

about: Returns the nearest integer that is greater than or equal to the one provided; rounds a number up.
description:
This will give you the nearest whole number that is greater than or equal to your number. It's called 'ceiling' because the ceiling is above you, and the ceiling block will return a number above your number.
example: 
ceiling(2.00001) will return 3
ceiling(2) will return 2
label: ceil
name: Ceiling

parameters.description: Number – The number to round up.

about: Chooses a random color from Hopscotch's color picker.
description: Can't decide on a color? Let Hopscotch choose for you! Your shape or background will change to a color randomly chosen from the ones we give you.
name: Random

about: Sets the RGB color based on the provided values for the red amount, green amount, and blue amount. RGB(0,0,0) is black, and RGB(255,255,255) is white.
description: Have a specific color in mind? Use RGB colors! Change the values of red, blue, and green to change the color. RGB color works on a scale from 0-255. All zeros gives you black while all 255s gives you white.
name: RGB

parameters.description: Red – the red value of the color.
parameters.label: R

parameters.description: Green – the green value of the color.
parameters.label: G

parameters.description: Blue – the blue value of the color.
parameters.label: B

about: Sets the HSB color based on the provided values for the hue, saturation, and brightness.
description:
Have a specific color in mind? Use HSB colors! Change the values of hue, saturation, and brightness to change the color. Hue works on a scale from 0-360 while the scale for saturation and brightness is 0-100.
All zeros gives you black while all 100s and 360 gives you white.
Try setting Hue to a shape's x position and seeing how the color changes as your shape moves across the screen.
name: HSB

parameters.description: Hue – the hue of the color.
parameters.label: H

parameters.description: Saturation – how vibrant the color should be.
parameters.label: S

parameters.description: Brightness – how bright the value should be.
parameters.label: B

about: A container block whose content is executed when the specified rule operator is triggered.
description: N/A – the app does not have a description for this block, as its operator determines its behavior.
label: When
name: When

parameters.description: Event – the event that should cause this rule to run.

about: A Rule Preview block that was likely used to preview an object's rule in older versions of Hopscotch.
description: N/A – this block no longer exists in the editor.
name: RulePreview
other_info: Little is known about this block. It was likely used to create a preview window for one rule at a time in older versions of Hopscotch, but the feature was later removed. This block remains in the webplayer file but is otherwise unused.

parameters.description: Unknown – it is currently unknown whether there were parameters for this block.

about: Runs when a scene starts.
description: Triggers when a project starts, and runs only once. You can use this to draw a background at the start of your project.
label: Game Starts
name: Game Starts
other_info: The discrepancy between the app's name and the block's action (when a scene starts) is due to the addition of scenes. Previously, there was only ever one scene in a project, so the rule would always run only once: when the entire game starts.

about: Runs when the specified item is tapped.
description:
Triggers when __ is tapped. You can choose what the __ is, like the screen or an object. A tap means you quickly touch the screen.
For an example, search the community for Color Switch. Each time you tap the screen, the ball moves.
name: Is Tapped

parameters.description: Target – An object that should be tapped to trigger this rule.

about: Detects when one object you choose touches another object.
community_links: When Not Touching – a great example on how to add a not touching using a touching block
description:
Triggers when two objects are touching each other on screen.
For an example, search the community for Escape the room. When the scissors touch the box, the box opens and reveals the next clue inside.
name: Is Touching

parameters.description: Object 1 – The first object involved in the collision.
Object 2 – The first object involved in the collision.
parameters.label: is touching

about: Detects when something is pressed with a finger.
community_links: Easy screen pressed code by jeff3321🇳🇱 – a mechanic detecting whether the screen is pressed
Wait Until Unpressed Code by RoadOcean – a mechanic which when something gets unpressed
description:
Triggers when __ is pressed. You can choose what the __ is, like the screen or an object. A press means you hold down on the screen.
For an example, search the community for Stick Ninja. Press the screen until the bridge is long enough for the ninja to cross it.
name: Is Pressed

parameters.description: Object – the object you choose to press with your finger.

useful_for: Changing the color of a square when you press it
Pressing an object it when it grows and deflates when it is not pressed
